aws::graph::propositions: # Experimental Airplane Engine Power Loss and Forced Landing Incident
The accident occurred in Bluffdale, Utah.
The accident occurred on May 3, 2014, at 19:45 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a 177MF LLC PITTS MODEL 12.
The defining event was loss of engine power (total).
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was WPR14LA185.
The aircraft registration was N177MF.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
The incident resulted in 2 minor injuries.
The private pilot had recently purchased the experimental airplane.
The flight was the second leg of the pilot's cross-country trip.
The pilot was flying the airplane home from the purchase location.
After the first leg, the pilot topped off the main fuel tank.
After the first leg, the pilot topped off the auxiliary (wing) fuel tanks.
According to the pilot's operating handbook (POH), the total usable fuel quantity was 53 gallons.
The pilot flew for about 3.5 hours before the incident.
The engine lost total power when the airplane was about 20 miles short of the planned destination.
The pilot was unable to restart the engine.
The pilot executed a forced landing in a field.
During the forced landing, the airplane nosed over.
The airplane came to rest inverted.
When the airplane was righted during recovery, about 4 to 5 gallons of fluid drained from the area.
The fluid drained from the area where the main fuel tank and the smoke oil tank were mounted.
It was not determined whether the drained fluid was fuel or a mixture of fuel and smoke oil.
The auxiliary tank was breached during the accident.
No determination of the auxiliary tank's postimpact fuel quantity could be made.
The engine was a highly modified aftermarket version of one of two different models.
The original engine manufacturer produced a 360-horsepower (hp) model.
The original engine manufacturer produced a 400-hp model.
No specific fuel burn chart for the modified engine had been developed.
The pilot's flight planning was based on fuel burn rates for a 360-hp engine.
The pilot's flight planning indicated that the flight would consume about 45 gallons of fuel.
Calculations using the POH fuel burn rates were for a 400-hp engine.
Calculations using the POH fuel burn rates indicated that the flight would consume between 51 and 58 gallons.
The fuel consumption range of 51 to 58 gallons depended on the power setting.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Bluffdale, Utah

## Date & Time: 
May 3, 2014, 19:45 Local

## Aircraft:
177MF LLC PITTS MODEL 12

## Defining Event:
Loss of engine power (total)

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
WPR14LA185

## Registration:
N177MF

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
2 Minor

## Analysis

The private pilot had recently purchased the experimental airplane, and the flight was the second leg of his cross-country trip to fly the airplane home from the purchase location. After the first leg, the pilot topped off the main and auxiliary (wing) fuel tanks, which, according to the pilot's operating handbook (POH) for the airplane, provided a total usable fuel quantity of 53 gallons. After flying about 3.5 hours, when the airplane was about 20 miles short of the planned destination, the engine lost total power, and the pilot was unable to restart it. During a forced landing in a field, the airplane nosed over and came to rest inverted. When the airplane was righted during recovery, about 4 to 5 gallons of fluid drained from the area where the main fuel tank and the smoke oil tank were mounted; however, it was not determined whether the fluid was fuel or a mixture of fuel and smoke oil. The auxiliary tank was breached, and no determination of its postimpact fuel quantity could be made.

The engine was a highly modified aftermarket version of one of two different models produced by the original engine manufacturer, a 360-horsepower (hp) model and a 400-hp model, and no specific fuel burn chart for the modified engine had been developed. The pilot's flight planning, which was based on fuel burn rates for a 360-hp engine, indicated that the flight would consume about 45 gallons of fuel. Calculations using the POH fuel burn rates, which were for a 400-hp engine, indicated that the flight would consume between 51 and 58 gallons, depending on the power setting.
